content: Do you feel that you have more rights than other tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens based on your beliefs and/or practices? If so, why should your beliefs and/or practices be considered superior and/or the benchmark by which to grant or deny others rights? If not, then do you believe that all tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens should have the same rights as you enjoy regardless of their beliefs and/or practices even if they are completely different than your own, even if you detest them?
reply: Do you feel that you have more rights than other tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens based on your beliefs and/or practices? If so, why should your beliefs and/or practices be considered superior and/or the benchmark by which to grant or deny others rights? If not, then do you believe that all tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens should have the same rights as you enjoy regardless of their beliefs and/or practices even if they are completely different than your own, even if you detest them?
title: As a tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizen....

content: Strange...I was just considering Robert Heinlein's proposition that service in the military was a prerequisite for citizenship. The context was the invasion of these boards by anti-military individuals who claim "freedom of speech" protects their right to be disruptive trolls. For Military.com purposes I will consider that posters with military service hav the priviledge of ignoring or shunning these people. As far as the question posed by the OP, No, I have the same rights as any other citizen. As a practitioner of the ethical standards of act deontology my beliefs and practices have more validity to me because I believe or do them. You are free to emulate my perfection. We, as Americans, have the God-Given-Right to be however we want to be, no matter if we are right or wrong as long as we don't actually injure anybody. I killed everybody I detested already. Have a nice day

content: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: quote: Originally posted by floersh: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: I think people who pay taxes should have more say then those who do not. Amen. Imo, only property owners should have the right to vote. Cool only property owners can vote. Now lets take a look at the definition of property. If I own it, it is my property. This computer which allows me access to this site is my property. My car, title is in my name, yep that's a piece of property. Will there be age limits on voting or can all property owners vote? Can it be expendable property? Can corporations vote under this new rule? They own a lot of property with warehouses, factories, trucks, inventory and office buildings.

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: quote: Originally posted by floersh: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: I think people who pay taxes should have more say then those who do not. Amen. Imo, only property owners should have the right to vote. Well, considering the trend that will only leave the banks. That's crap. If you pay taxes you should be able to vote period. Your vote is your only "representation" if you can even consider it that. Honestly, in the end, everyone would vote, anyways...while not everyone pays property or income tax, everyone does pay sales taxes. Plus, many localities lower or eliminate property and/or income taxes in favor of sales taxes. Some states use sales taxes in lieu of income taxes. Everybody pays sales tax. So, unless you want to go down the road of "you only vote at the level which you pay taxes", but then you might have people voting in state but not local or federal, or some other combination based on whether or not you pay sales taxes. Nobody is going to do that. Unless, of course, we do away with property and all income taxes at the local, state and fed level in favor of sales taxes...then everybody has "paid for" their vote.
quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: quote: Originally posted by floersh: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: I think people who pay taxes should have more say then those who do not. Amen. Imo, only property owners should have the right to vote. Well, considering the trend that will only leave the banks. That's crap. If you pay taxes you should be able to vote period. Your vote is your only "representation" if you can even consider it that.
reply: Honestly, in the end, everyone would vote, anyways...while not everyone pays property or income tax, everyone does pay sales taxes. Plus, many localities lower or eliminate property and/or income taxes in favor of sales taxes. Some states use sales taxes in lieu of income taxes. Everybody pays sales tax. So, unless you want to go down the road of "you only vote at the level which you pay taxes", but then you might have people voting in state but not local or federal, or some other combination based on whether or not you pay sales taxes. Nobody is going to do that. Unless, of course, we do away with property and all income taxes at the local, state and fed level in favor of sales taxes...then everybody has "paid for" their vote.

content: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: Do you feel that you have more rights than other tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens based on your beliefs and/or practices? If so, why should your beliefs and/or practices be considered superior and/or the benchmark by which to grant or deny others rights? If not, then do you believe that all tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens should have the same rights as you enjoy regardless of their beliefs and/or practices even if they are completely different than your own, even if you detest them? Personally I feel as though everyone SHOULD be equal, however it seems it depends on what state you live in whether or not you are TREATED equal. Example: Miss California vs Miss Rhode Island. Both had racey photos yet only Miss California was chastized by the left wingers and the media about it. Only conclusion one can come up with is it was because of her BELIEF in marraige being between a man and a women. But you're completely ignoring the key issue here. The LAW treats them both the SAME. Individuals can have their opinions, and other people can like or dislike their opinions all they want. Donald Trump had the right to keep or fire Miss CA because his pageant is a privately-funded enterprise. Perez Hilton (the useless gossipy little bimbo that he is) has the right to have a hissy fit. The news has the right to report on it with whichever perspective it wants. And so on. Why? Because they're private individuals. The GOVERNMENT and the LAW, however, must grant ALL people the same rights, freedoms, and protections. So, were Miss CA and Miss RI treated the same way? Legally, yes, and that's the only issue. In fact, this wasn't an issue of law whatsoever, so the law didn't even get involved. This was all a matter of private business and private citizens' opinions. If Miss CA were to apply for a job and were to be denied the job because of her religion, then that would be discrimination, and the law would step in. So, what's your problem? Under the law, she was treated with all the same protections as everyone else. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Whirled_Peas, Thu 14 May 2009 12:36 PM

Both had racey photos yet only Miss California was chastized by the left wingers and the media about it. Only conclusion one can come up with is it was because of her BELIEF in marraige being between a man and a women.

The news has the right to report on it with whichever perspective it wants. And so on. Why? Because they're private individuals. The GOVERNMENT and the LAW, however, must grant ALL people the same rights, freedoms, and protections. So, were Miss CA and Miss RI treated the same way? Legally, yes, and that's the only issue. In fact, this wasn't an issue of law whatsoever, so the law didn't even get involved. This was all a matter of private business and private citizens' opinions. If Miss CA were to apply for a job and were to be denied the job because of her religion, then that would be discrimination, and the law would step in. So, what's your problem? content: Strange...I was just considering Robert Heinlein's proposition that service in the military was a prerequisite for citizenship. The context was the invasion of these boards by anti-military individuals who claim "freedom of speech" protects their right to be disruptive trolls. For Military.com purposes I will consider that posters with military service hav the priviledge of ignoring or shunning these people. As far as the question posed by the OP, No, I have the same rights as any other citizen. As a practitioner of the ethical standards of act deontology my beliefs and practices have more validity to me because I believe or do them. You are free to emulate my perfection. We, as Americans, have the God-Given-Right to be however we want to be, no matter if we are right or wrong as long as we don't actually injure anybody. I killed everybody I detested already. Have a nice day

For the record, LOA1 you hit the nail on the head and got where I'm going, because it is about Freedom of Speech as well as other Freedoms and your analysis about Miss CA vs RI was a good one. Even though I was never asked on the issue or blogged about it, I too believe Miss CA was given a raw deal unless it's written somewhere in the pageant rules that your not allowed to voice an opinion when asked that is contrary to what the pageant believes and she signed a statement to agree to those rules.

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: quote: Originally posted by floersh: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: I think people who pay taxes should have more say then those who do not. Amen. Imo, only property owners should have the right to vote. Well, considering the trend that will only leave the banks. That's crap. If you pay taxes you should be able to vote period. Your vote is your only "representation" if you can even consider it that. Honestly, in the end, everyone would vote, anyways...while not everyone pays property or income tax, everyone does pay sales taxes. Plus, many localities lower or eliminate property and/or income taxes in favor of sales taxes. Some states use sales taxes in lieu of income taxes. Everybody pays sales tax. So, unless you want to go down the road of "you only vote at the level which you pay taxes", but then you might have people voting in state but not local or federal, or some other combination based on whether or not you pay sales taxes. Nobody is going to do that. Unless, of course, we do away with property and all income taxes at the local, state and fed level in favor of sales taxes...then everybody has "paid for" their vote.
quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: quote: Originally posted by floersh: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: I think people who pay taxes should have more say then those who do not. Your vote is your only "representation" if you can even consider it that.

So, unless you want to go down the road of "you only vote at the level which you pay taxes", but then you might have people voting in state but not local or federal, or some other combination based on whether or not you pay sales taxes. Nobody is going to do that. Unless, of course, we do away with property and all income taxes at the local, state and fed level in favor of sales taxes...then everybody has "paid for" their vote.

content: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by Sgt_Salaam: Do you feel that you have more rights than other tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens based on your beliefs and/or practices? If so, why should your beliefs and/or practices be considered superior and/or the benchmark by which to grant or deny others rights? If not, then do you believe that all tax-paying, law-abiding, US Citizens should have the same rights as you enjoy regardless of their beliefs and/or practices even if they are completely different than your own, even if you detest them? Personally I feel as though everyone SHOULD be equal, however it seems it depends on what state you live in whether or not you are TREATED equal. Example: Miss California vs Miss Rhode Island. Both had racey photos yet only Miss California was chastized by the left wingers and the media about it. Only conclusion one can come up with is it was because of her BELIEF in marraige being between a man and a women. But you're completely ignoring the key issue here. The LAW treats them both the SAME. Individuals can have their opinions, and other people can like or dislike their opinions all they want. Donald Trump had the right to keep or fire Miss CA because his pageant is a privately-funded enterprise. Perez Hilton (the useless gossipy little bimbo that he is) has the right to have a hissy fit. The news has the right to report on it with whichever perspective it wants. And so on. Why? Because they're private individuals. The GOVERNMENT and the LAW, however, must grant ALL people the same rights, freedoms, and protections. So, were Miss CA and Miss RI treated the same way? Legally, yes, and that's the only issue. In fact, this wasn't an issue of law whatsoever, so the law didn't even get involved. This was all a matter of private business and private citizens' opinions. If Miss CA were to apply for a job and were to be denied the job because of her religion, then that would be discrimination, and the law would step in. So, what's your problem? Under the law, she was treated with all the same protections as everyone else. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Whirled_Peas, Thu 14 May 2009 12:36 PM

Both had racey photos yet only Miss California was chastized by the left wingers and the media about it. Only conclusion one can come up with is it was because of her BELIEF in marraige being between a man and a women.

In fact, this wasn't an issue of law whatsoever, so the law didn't even get involved. This was all a matter of private business and private citizens' opinions. If Miss CA were to apply for a job and were to be denied the job because of her religion, then that would be discrimination, and the law would step in. So, what's your problem?
